intro: Ipomopsis congesta var. pseudotypica, commonly known as the Sierra starflower, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is characterized by its showy, star-shaped blue to violet flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows in open, sunny habitats such as meadows and rocky slopes. Its leaves are narrow and lance-shaped, and it produces small, capsule-like fruits that contain numerous seeds. It is a member of the Campanulaceae family, which includes other flowering plants with tubular or bell-shaped flowers.
